shayla.walker30: Hey girl hey! Well you know where we started in our Magazine writing class at sac state being the only two black women in class. We instantly clicked! I am so proud to see you blossom and shine! I'm the Director over Student activities at San Joaquin Delta College and last week opened up a food pantry on campus to address food insecurity of students. Hard work takes sacrifice, but I want you to know how much of an inspiration you are to me and I am blessed to have met such an amazing human being in college. Thank you Elaine for your positive words and being an advocate for the black community and women ❤️

ceedub24: I absolutely this! Another first generation uni student & foster kid at the time I wanted Northwestern but was getting financial assistance at @illinois1867 so I went there. So happy I did! hannahs_hands: Very proud of my college freshman who was born with physical challenges and is confined to using a wheelchair BUT has BUSTED HER BUTT and graduated with a 4.0 GPA, inducted into the NSHSS, recognized ceremoniously as a STATE SCHOLAR and has EARNED a few academic scholarships despite being born with a severe physical condition. Knocking down all kinds of stereotypes. She is the only one at her college now rolling around in s wheelchair and doesn’t let any of the “stares” phase her. lauraksawyier: Thank you for sharing. I was kicked out at 15 and again at 19 by each divorced parent. Graduated college early to help reduce my student loan draw. Lived on friends couches, shared their beds, until I finally moved into an apartment in nyc that illegally housed four people. My mattresses placed on the floor before a friend of mine gave me their old bed frame when they were getting a new one. People in my life told me they’re we’re worried that I would fail, but really, I was feeding my dream of living in nyc and working my way up at a design firm, fulfilling my creative passion that was mildly stifled by my stepparent choosing my college and telling me to study business (which I changed). Then I moved to another city to be with the man I would later marry, try to continue that career, but then made a choice to pivot into fashion styling because I so passionately loved this industry and wanted to explore the powers and impact of helping women dress to feel their best. To light up my dream and push to grow. To help other women seek and find their own power within that I found and continue to tune on my own journey. And now, all of that is yielding growth and pride. The resentment is reduced to nothing, that once overwhelmed my spirit. Integrity and perseverance keep me pointed to my North Star, as does reading other people’s stories about their own journeys. ♥️
